text: creo que lo de que microservices no son para todo el mundo no es nada nuevo, y se ha hablado de eso des del principio

elements.text: creo que lo de que microservices no son para todo el mundo no es nada nuevo, y se ha hablado de eso des del principio

text:
de hecho <@U2YH82SRM> en building microservices hay esto en el primer capitulo:
```No Silver Bullet
Before we finish, I should call out that microservices are no free lunch or silver bullet, and make for a bad choice as a golden hammer. They have all the associated complexities of distributed systems, and while we have learned a lot about how to manage distributed systems well (which we'll discuss throughout the book) it is still hard. If you're coming from a monolithic system point of view, you'll have to get much better at handling deployment, testing, and monitoring to unlock the benefits we've covered so far. You'll also need to think differently about how you scale your systems and ensure that they are resilient. Don't also be surprised if things like distributed transactions or CAP theorem start giving you headaches, either!

Every company, organization, and system is different. A number of factors will play into whether or not microservices are right for you, and how aggressive you can be in adopting them. Throughout each chapter in this book I'll attempt to give you guidance highlighting the potential pitfalls, which should help you chart a steady path.```

elements.text: de hecho
en building microservices hay esto en el primer capitulo:

No Silver Bullet
Before we finish, I should call out that microservices are no free lunch or silver bullet, and make for a bad choice as a golden hammer. They have all the associated complexities of distributed systems, and while we have learned a lot about how to manage distributed systems well (which we'll discuss throughout the book) it is still hard. If you're coming from a monolithic system point of view, you'll have to get much better at handling deployment, testing, and monitoring to unlock the benefits we've covered so far. You'll also need to think differently about how you scale your systems and ensure that they are resilient. Don't also be surprised if things like distributed transactions or CAP theorem start giving you headaches, either!

Every company, organization, and system is different. A number of factors will play into whether or not microservices are right for you, and how aggressive you can be in adopting them. Throughout each chapter in this book I'll attempt to give you guidance highlighting the potential pitfalls, which should help you chart a steady path.

text: <@U0142SPE1B3> has joined the channel

Hola, yo estoy migrando una aplicación con Active Record y código bastante malo a DDD, hemos creado una capa repositorio que permite hacer CQRS sobre active record, y por ahora no va mal, pero tenemos claro que cuando terminemos de hacer refactoring del resto de la aplicación, pasaremos a doctrine.

elements.text: Hola, yo estoy migrando una aplicación con Active Record y código bastante malo a DDD, hemos creado una capa repositorio que permite hacer CQRS sobre active record, y por ahora no va mal, pero tenemos claro que cuando terminemos de hacer refactoring del resto de la aplicación, pasaremos a doctrine.

text: En mi caso, las clases Active Record, no tienen absolutamente nada que ver con las entidades, ni el mismo número de tablas, ni el mismo número de campos.... tenemos un mapper entre entity los AR. Lo que cuenta el artículo está demasiado acoplado...
